column1: 1	Pop	"Pop music (a term that derives from ""popular"") is a genre of popular music that originated in its modern form in the Western world during the 1950s and 1960s
column2: deriving from rock and roll. The terms ""popular music"" and ""pop music"" are often used interchangeably
column3: although the former describes all music that is popular (and can include any style)."

column1: 4	Rock	"Rock music is a genre of popular music that originated as ""rock and roll"" in the United States in the 1950s
column2: and developed into a range of different styles in the 1960s and later
column3: particularly in the United Kingdom and the United States. It has its roots in 1940s' and 1950s' rock and roll
column5: rhythm and blues and country music. Rock music also drew strongly on a number of other genres such as electric blues and folk

column1: 5	Grunge	"Grunge (sometimes referred to as the Seattle sound) is a subgenre of alternative rock that emerged during the mid-1980s in the American state of Washington
column2: particularly in Seattle. The early grunge movement revolved around Seattle's independent record label Sub Pop
column3: but by the early 1990s its popularity had spread
column4: with grunge acts in California and other parts of the U.S. building strong followings and signing major record deals."

column1: 6	Hard Rock	"Hard rock is a loosely defined subgenre of rock music that began in the mid-1960s
column3: psychedelic and blues rock movements. It is typified by a heavy use of aggressive vocals
column7: and often accompanied with pianos and keyboards."

column1: 7	Punk Rock	"Punk rock (or simply punk) is a rock music genre that developed between 1974 and 1976 in the United States
column3: and Australia. Rooted in garage rock and other forms of what is now known as protopunk music
column4: punk rock bands eschewed perceived excesses of mainstream 1970s rock."
